principles.name: Two or Three Priorities Mental Framework
principles.description: 'I don't have it mapped out, but I do have two or three priorities in my head at all times.' Operating with a small, manageable set of concurrent focus areas rather than detailed plans.
principles.theme: Financial Foundation and Client Confidence Building

principles.name: Financial Analysis as Starting Point Standard
principles.description: 'I'm almost always in what is on the front of their mind at the beginning, it's my financial background. So I want to deliver for a couple of reasons. One, it's what I do. And two, it is their weakness.' Leveraging core strength to address client weakness consistently.
principles.theme: Financial Foundation and Client Confidence Building

principles.name: Gross Margin Concentration Insight
principles.description: 'The first victory was explaining to the owner that 50% of his gross margin dollars come from only a third of his inventory.' Revealing hidden profit concentration patterns that owners don't see.
principles.theme: Financial Foundation and Client Confidence Building

principles.name: Cash Understanding as Primary Purpose
principles.description: 'I always use it for the primary purpose, and that is to understand their cash. The ins and outs of cash because I have to be comfortable with it, and they have to be comfortable with it because some people may be running out of cash and not even know.'
principles.theme: Financial Foundation and Client Confidence Building

principles.name: Net Income vs. Cash Mistake Recognition
principles.description: 'Net income is the same as cash. That's the number one mistake nonfinancial people make, without a doubt.' Understanding the fundamental confusion between profit reporting and cash flow reality.
principles.theme: Financial Foundation and Client Confidence Building

patterns.name: Financial Confidence Building Process
patterns.description: Start with financial analysis to establish credibility while immediately addressing owner financial knowledge gaps without making them feel inadequate.
patterns.context: Early consulting relationships where establishing expertise and trust while managing client ego around financial literacy is crucial.
patterns.theme: Financial Foundation and Client Confidence Building

patterns.name: Data Quality Assessment Before Analysis
patterns.description: Look for trends and wide variations in financial accounts first 'to figure out whether I even have confidence in what I'm looking at' before drawing conclusions.
patterns.context: Financial analysis where data reliability must be established before insights can be trusted or acted upon.
patterns.theme: Financial Foundation and Client Confidence Building

patterns.name: Hidden Profit Pattern Revelation
patterns.description: Use financial analysis to reveal profit concentration patterns that owners don't recognize, like gross margin concentration in inventory segments.
patterns.context: Business optimization where owners lack visibility into which aspects of their business actually drive profitability.
patterns.theme: Financial Foundation and Client Confidence Building

examples.name: Two or Three Priorities Framework
examples.content: Dan operates with 'two or three priorities in my head at all times' rather than detailed maps. For a business targeting '$5 million of enterprise value,' his priorities are: optimize warehouse operations, better inventory control, and financial reporting improvement 'because there is none right now.'
examples.theme: Financial Foundation and Client Confidence Building

examples.name: Gross Margin Concentration Discovery
examples.content: Dan's first victory was 'explaining to the owner that 50% of his gross margin dollars come from only a third of his inventory,' leading to the question 'Why are we carrying so much stuff that barely moves?' This represents his standard approach of starting with financial analysis.
examples.theme: Financial Foundation and Client Confidence Building

examples.name: Financial Ego Management
examples.content: Dan's key soft skill in financial analysis is 'not making them feel like an idiot.' He starts with 'It's okay that you don't understand this. That's why I'm here' because 'early on in almost every relationship, the owner is apologetic to me about their lack of financial knowledge, and I just have to put them at ease.'
examples.theme: Financial Foundation and Client Confidence Building

principles.name: Verify Claims Through Independent Analysis
principles.description: 'Until I prove it, I'm not going to say that you're wrong. I'm not going to say that you're right. I just have to know for myself that it's true.' Independent verification of claimed performance metrics, even from reputable sources.
principles.theme: Verification and Growth Management

principles.name: Advisor Role in Growth Moderation
principles.description: When owner gets excited about scaling ('why don't we just increase it 20% every month'), respond with 'Well, let's just slow down a little bit. Let's just be a little bit more deliberate with that and make sure we understand what we're doing.'
principles.theme: Verification and Growth Management

principles.name: Framing Role as Company Enablement
principles.description: To warehouse manager: 'Dan really thinks he's got the formula figured out and he really wants to grow. I said my job is to make sure the rest of the company can keep up with his plans.' Positioning as supporting growth rather than controlling it.
principles.theme: Verification and Growth Management

principles.name: Urgent vs. Important Priority Correction
principles.description: 'We have a priority problem here... We're not working on what's important. We're working on what's urgent. All day long.' Distinguishing between crisis management and strategic focus.
principles.theme: Verification and Growth Management

principles.name: Badgering for Delegation Acceptance
principles.description: 'The way I'm getting there is I am badger her with texts and requests for meetings... Just give it to me.' Persistent pressure to force owners to delegate tasks they shouldn't be doing.
principles.theme: Verification and Growth Management

patterns.name: Claims Verification Process
patterns.description: Independently verify performance claims from external vendors or internal reports, even when sources are reputable, to establish baseline truth.
patterns.context: Business optimization where claimed performance metrics may be inflated or measured incorrectly, requiring independent analysis.
patterns.theme: Verification and Growth Management

patterns.name: Growth Enthusiasm Moderation
patterns.description: Counterbalance owner excitement about scaling with measured, deliberate planning to ensure sustainable growth rather than reckless expansion.
patterns.context: Successful businesses where initial wins create overconfidence about scaling capabilities and speed.
patterns.theme: Verification and Growth Management

patterns.name: Persistent Delegation Enforcement
patterns.description: Use persistent pressure and communication to force owners to delegate operational tasks so they can focus on strategic activities like sales.
patterns.context: Owner-operated businesses where founders resist delegating even routine tasks that prevent them from higher-value activities.
patterns.theme: Verification and Growth Management

examples.name: Google Ads Verification and Growth Moderation
examples.content: Dan found Google Ads represented 'the single biggest expense in overhead' with claimed 10x ROI. He said 'Until I prove it, I'm not going to say that you're wrong... I just have to know for myself that it's true.' The actual ROI was 7.6x. When the owner wanted to 'increase it 20% every month,' Dan advised 'let's just slow down a little bit. Let's just be a little bit more deliberate.'
examples.theme: Verification and Growth Management

examples.name: Urgent vs. Important Priority Problem
examples.content: With a business owner 45 days behind in billing with no cash, Dan identified the core issue: 'We have a priority problem here... We're not working on what's important. We're working on what's urgent. All day long.' He forces delegation by 'badger her with texts and requests' until she agrees to hand over operational tasks.
examples.theme: Verification and Growth Management

examples.name: Company Enablement Framing
examples.content: When meeting the warehouse manager, Dan framed his role: 'Dan really thinks he's got the formula figured out and he really wants to grow. I said my job is to make sure the rest of the company can keep up with his plans.' This positions him as supporting the owner's vision rather than imposing external control.
examples.theme: Verification and Growth Management

principles.name: Creative Owners Focus
principles.description: 'I help creative owners get back to doing what they were doing that made the business great.' Core mission focused on enabling founders to return to their strengths.
principles.theme: Neutral Advisory and Creative Owner Enablement

principles.name: Switzerland Neutrality Model
principles.description: 'I am Switzerland if the employee... I freely admit I am being paid by the owner, but I work for the company, and I'm going to do the... I'm going to work in the best interest of the company, not the owner.' Neutral position between owner and employees.
principles.theme: Neutral Advisory and Creative Owner Enablement

principles.name: Leadership Term Rejection
principles.description: 'I won't say leadership because I don't think that word means anything anymore. It's just squishy, and people just run around saying that they're practicing leadership.' Preferring concrete terms like accountability and responsibility.
principles.theme: Neutral Advisory and Creative Owner Enablement

principles.name: Accountability and Responsibility Over Leadership
principles.description: 'I help people become more accountable, and I help them take on more responsibility... I work to figure out who owns what in the organization and who is capable of taking on more and helping them get it.'
principles.theme: Neutral Advisory and Creative Owner Enablement

principles.name: Early Passion for Influence and Events
principles.description: 'The passion was to be involved in influence events in effect. I don't know if it was to lead or not... I had a passion for being class president.' Early drive to shape outcomes and be central to important activities.
principles.theme: Neutral Advisory and Creative Owner Enablement

principles.name: Partner Role Model Disillusionment
principles.description: 'Very few of the partners served as very good role models for me... they were rich, but I don't know that they were leading lives that really interested me.' Success without lifestyle appeal led to career redirection.
principles.theme: Neutral Advisory and Creative Owner Enablement

patterns.name: Multi-Role Capability Deployment
patterns.description: Function as CFO, warehouse manager, treasurer, accountant, advisor, board member, integrator, strategist, or CEO depending on business needs.
patterns.context: Small business consulting where role flexibility allows filling multiple organizational gaps as needed.
patterns.theme: Neutral Advisory and Creative Owner Enablement

patterns.name: Company-First Allegiance Declaration
patterns.description: Explicitly state loyalty to company interests rather than owner preferences, creating trust with employees while maintaining owner relationship.
patterns.context: Organizational consulting where employee buy-in is crucial but owner funding creates potential conflict of interest.
patterns.theme: Neutral Advisory and Creative Owner Enablement

examples.name: Comprehensive Expertise Inventory
examples.content: Dan's mini-expertise areas include: 'Financial analysis, accounting, bookkeeping, sales tax planning, relationship building, pricing, margin analysis, inventory analysis, vendor negotiation... delegation model... clarifying roles and responsibilities. Being a sounding board and being willing to tell the owner what they want to hear, whether they want to hear it or not.'
examples.theme: Neutral Advisory and Creative Owner Enablement

examples.name: Switzerland Neutrality Metaphor
examples.content: Dan describes his role as 'Switzerland' to employees: 'I freely admit I am being paid by the owner, but I work for the company, and I'm going to work in the best interest of the company, not the owner, understanding that if I do something that is not in the best interest of the owner, I'll get fired.'
examples.theme: Neutral Advisory and Creative Owner Enablement

examples.name: Early Passion for Influence
examples.content: Dan traces his motivation back to high school: 'The passion was to be involved in influence events in effect. I don't know if it was to lead or not... I had a passion for being class president.' Early career passion was 'money and the prestige' with 'the goal was partner.'
examples.theme: Neutral Advisory and Creative Owner Enablement

examples.name: Partner Role Model Disillusionment
examples.content: After having children, Dan realized 'very few of the partners served as very good role models for me... they were rich, but I don't know that they were leading lives that really interested me.' This led him to leave the partnership track.
examples.theme: Neutral Advisory and Creative Owner Enablement

principles.name: Six Core Business Benefits
principles.description: Primary value delivered: 'Financial clarity, sounding board for the owner, the person who ensures the execution of the owner's wishes, improved profitability, improved accountability' plus 'a happier team.' These represent the complete value proposition.
principles.theme: Comprehensive Value Delivery and Career Evolution

principles.name: Happier Team as Afterthought Recognition
principles.description: 'Yeah, a happier team' added after initial five benefits, suggesting this outcome is valued but not always consciously positioned as primary benefit.
principles.theme: Comprehensive Value Delivery and Career Evolution

principles.name: Trusted Advisor Continuity
principles.description: 'In some ways, I think it's no different than coming right out of college into a public accounting firm. I was still working with business owners in a much more specialized capacity, but I was still advising, and I was acting as a trusted advisor.' Career consistency in advisory role.
principles.theme: Comprehensive Value Delivery and Career Evolution

principles.name: Unconscious Career Choice
principles.description: 'I don't even know that it was conscious' about choosing accounting, suggesting career evolution happened organically rather than through strategic planning.
principles.theme: Comprehensive Value Delivery and Career Evolution

principles.name: Logic and Symmetry Appeal
principles.description: 'Probably the symmetry of dividends equalling credits and the logic of it. So, I got it.' Attraction to systematic, logical frameworks that have clear rules and balance.
principles.theme: Comprehensive Value Delivery and Career Evolution

principles.name: Practical Field Selection
principles.description: 'Probably at the time, I knew it was a very solid field to go into.' Career choice influenced by stability and security considerations alongside intellectual appeal.
principles.theme: Comprehensive Value Delivery and Career Evolution

patterns.name: Six-Benefit Value Proposition
patterns.description: Deliver financial clarity, owner advisory support, execution management, profitability improvement, accountability enhancement, and team happiness as comprehensive business value.
patterns.context: Business consulting where multiple stakeholder benefits need to be articulated clearly for different audiences (owners, employees, prospects).
patterns.theme: Comprehensive Value Delivery and Career Evolution

patterns.name: Organic Career Evolution
patterns.description: Allow career development to happen through natural attraction to logical systems and advisory relationships rather than forcing strategic career planning.
patterns.context: Professional development where authentic interests and natural abilities guide career direction more effectively than forced planning.
patterns.theme: Comprehensive Value Delivery and Career Evolution

examples.name: Six Core Business Benefits
examples.content: Dan's value proposition includes five primary benefits: 'Financial clarity, sounding board for the owner, the person who ensures the execution of the owner's wishes, improved profitability, improved accountability.' He adds a sixth: 'a happier team' when prompted, noting 'That a big one.'
examples.theme: Comprehensive Value Delivery and Career Evolution

examples.name: Unconscious Accounting Attraction
examples.content: When asked what attracted him to accounting, Dan responds 'God I ask myself that every day... I don't even know that it was conscious.' He traces it to high school bookkeeping: 'Probably the symmetry of dividends equalling credits and the logic of it. So, I got it' plus knowing 'it was a very solid field to go into.'
examples.theme: Comprehensive Value Delivery and Career Evolution

examples.name: Trusted Advisor Continuity
examples.content: Dan sees his current work as continuous with his early career: 'in some ways, I think it's no different than coming right out of college into a public accounting firm. I was still working with business owners in a much more specialized capacity, but I was still advising, and I was acting as a trusted advisor.'
examples.theme: Comprehensive Value Delivery and Career Evolution

principles.name: Early Passion for Influence and Events
principles.description: 'The passion was to be involved in influence events in effect. I don't know if it was to lead or not... I had a passion for playing soccer. I didn't have a passion for school. I had a passion for being class president.' Early drive focused on impact and involvement rather than pure leadership.
principles.theme: Career Evolution Through Life Stage Values

principles.name: Promotion-Focused vs. Work-Focused Passion
principles.description: 'I had a passion to be successful at the CPA firm... I was working to be promoted, but that was the passion. It wasn't about the work itself.' Motivation driven by advancement rather than intrinsic work satisfaction.
principles.theme: Career Evolution Through Life Stage Values

principles.name: Money and Prestige as Early Drivers
principles.description: 'That would have been the money and the prestige... because the goal was partner.' Clear acknowledgment of external validation and financial success as primary motivators.
principles.theme: Career Evolution Through Life Stage Values

principles.name: Role Model Disillusionment
principles.description: 'Very few of the partners served as very good role models for me... they were rich, but I don't know that they were leading lives that really interested me.' Success without lifestyle appeal led to career redirection.
principles.theme: Career Evolution Through Life Stage Values

principles.name: Uncertainty and Unpredictability Craving
principles.description: 'I missed the uncertainty of a client problem or a client picking up the phone and calling... Same shit, different day is a little bit extreme, but it was far more predictable than unpredictable.' Need for variety and surprise over stability.
principles.theme: Career Evolution Through Life Stage Values

principles.name: Family as Career Catalyst
principles.description: 'When the kids came along... I began to realize... The cost in hours required was not going to be worth it.' Children created values clarification that changed career trajectory.
principles.theme: Career Evolution Through Life Stage Values

patterns.name: Values Evolution Through Life Stages
patterns.description: Allow major life changes (like having children) to prompt reevaluation of career priorities and role model quality rather than maintaining fixed goals.
patterns.context: Career development where external success markers may conflict with evolving personal values and lifestyle preferences.
patterns.theme: Career Evolution Through Life Stage Values

patterns.name: Unpredictability as Energy Source
patterns.description: Seek work environments that provide uncertainty and client-driven variety rather than predictable corporate routines, even when the predictable work is enjoyable.
patterns.context: Professional choices where stimulation and variety matter more than security and routine for maintaining engagement and energy.
patterns.theme: Career Evolution Through Life Stage Values

examples.name: High School Passion Foundation
examples.content: Dan's earliest passion was 'to be involved in influence events in effect. I don't know if it was to lead or not' including 'passion for playing soccer... passion for being class president' but notably 'I didn't have a passion for school.' This established a pattern of wanting to influence outcomes and be central to important activities.
examples.theme: Career Evolution Through Life Stage Values

examples.name: CPA Firm Passion vs. Work Content
examples.content: Early business passion was 'to be successful at the CPA firm... I was working to be promoted, but that was the passion. It wasn't about the work itself.' The motivation was 'money and the prestige... because the goal was partner' rather than intrinsic work satisfaction.
examples.theme: Career Evolution Through Life Stage Values

examples.name: Role Model Disillusionment and Career Shift
examples.content: Having children prompted realization that CPA firm partners 'were rich, but I don't know that they were leading lives that really interested me.' This led to leaving accounting, but corporate life was too predictable: 'I missed the uncertainty of a client problem or a client picking up the phone and calling.'
examples.theme: Career Evolution Through Life Stage Values

principles.name: External Reliance Activation
principles.description: 'I have to know someone is relying on me. I can't just do it. Not that I can't do it for myself, but for me to reach a level of intensity of not only quality but just thought process, I need to know that the output will be used by someone else.'
principles.theme: Stakeholder-Dependent Performance Optimization

patterns.name: Stakeholder-Dependent Performance
patterns.description: Peak performance and flow states require knowing that others are depending on the output, which elevates both quality and thought process intensity beyond what self-directed work can achieve.
patterns.context: Personal projects or self-directed work where external accountability and impact are needed to reach optimal performance levels.
patterns.theme: Stakeholder-Dependent Performance Optimization

examples.name: External vs Internal Project Performance Difference
examples.content: When asked about achieving flow state on his own projects versus external consulting work, Dan reveals that he needs to 'know someone is relying on me' to reach peak 'intensity of not only quality but just thought process.' While he can work for himself, optimal performance requires knowing 'the output will be used by someone else.'
examples.theme: Stakeholder-Dependent Performance Optimization

principles.name: Passion for Problem-Based Helping
principles.description: 'I just help someone has a problem... When we're finished talking about it or I go off and do something and come back to them, they feel better for it. It's not about giving an answer.' Passion centered on providing relief and improvement rather than solution delivery.
principles.theme: Facilitative Helping Over Solution Provision

principles.name: Teaching as Career Analog
principles.description: 'The closest thing that comes to mind is teaching... you're not helping with a current problem but you're taking all of your experience and helping them to understand the problem and maybe avoid them down the road.' Similar helping function with prevention focus.
principles.theme: Facilitative Helping Over Solution Provision

principles.name: Limited Current Interests
principles.description: 'Being a right-wing reactionary is really important to me on a daily basis... My interest, even in sports, is waning a little bit. Outside of family, I read and stuff... Don't have any other interests.' Narrow range of current passions beyond work and family.
principles.theme: Facilitative Helping Over Solution Provision

principles.name: Evolution from Giving Answers to Leading to Solutions
principles.description: 'Earlier... I thought help meant giving answers. Help really means leading people to a better solution.' Fundamental shift in helping philosophy from directive to facilitative approach.
principles.theme: Facilitative Helping Over Solution Provision

patterns.name: Problem Relief Over Solution Provision
patterns.description: Focus on helping people feel better about their problems rather than necessarily providing definitive answers or solutions.
patterns.context: Consulting or advisory work where emotional relief and clarity may be more valuable than specific technical solutions.
patterns.theme: Facilitative Helping Over Solution Provision

patterns.name: Preventive Teaching Approach
patterns.description: Use experience to help people understand and potentially avoid future problems rather than just solving current issues.
patterns.context: Mentoring or educational roles where long-term development is more important than immediate problem-solving.
patterns.theme: Facilitative Helping Over Solution Provision

patterns.name: Helping Philosophy Evolution
patterns.description: Transition from directive advice-giving to facilitative guidance that leads people to discover their own better solutions.
patterns.context: Professional development where effectiveness requires moving from expert-driven to client-driven problem-solving approaches.
patterns.theme: Facilitative Helping Over Solution Provision

examples.name: Current Passion Definition
examples.content: When asked about passion for his current work, Dan explains: 'I just help someone has a problem... When we're finished talking about it or I go off and do something and come back to them, they feel better for it. It's not about giving an answer.' The satisfaction comes from providing relief rather than solutions.
examples.theme: Facilitative Helping Over Solution Provision

examples.name: Teaching as Career Analog
examples.content: When asked about applying his skills to another career, Dan identifies teaching: 'you're not helping with a current problem but you're taking all of your experience and helping them to understand the problem and maybe avoid them down the road.' This represents the same helping function with a prevention focus.
examples.theme: Facilitative Helping Over Solution Provision

examples.name: Help Philosophy Evolution
examples.content: Dan describes a fundamental shift in his understanding: 'Earlier... I thought help meant giving answers. Help really means leading people to a better solution.' This represents evolution from directive to facilitative helping approach.
examples.theme: Facilitative Helping Over Solution Provision

principles.name: Root Cause Over Surface Solutions
principles.description: 'Root cause... You'll never get to the root cause in the first conversation, obviously. But even two or three conversations in, you still haven't drilled down into the core issue.' Emphasis on deep causal understanding rather than quick fixes.
principles.theme: Deep Causal Analysis Over Quick Fixes

principles.name: Tool-Throwing as False Victory
principles.description: 'What a lot of people in my position do is just throw ideas and tools out to try to solve those surface-level issues and then declare victory. But it hasn't necessarily built a stronger company.' Critique of superficial consulting approaches.
principles.theme: Deep Causal Analysis Over Quick Fixes

principles.name: Multi-Conversation Root Cause Discovery
principles.description: Root cause analysis requires patience across 'two or three conversations' or more, rejecting the pressure for immediate problem identification and solution.
principles.theme: Deep Causal Analysis Over Quick Fixes

principles.name: Fractional Advisor Identity
principles.description: 'It's that fractional advisor. You know, COO CFO.' Current role conception as hybrid operational and financial leadership rather than pure consulting.
principles.theme: Deep Causal Analysis Over Quick Fixes

patterns.name: Deep Causal Investigation Process
patterns.description: Resist pressure for quick solutions by systematically drilling down through multiple conversations to identify root causes rather than addressing symptoms.
patterns.context: Business consulting where surface problems are often symptoms of deeper organizational or systemic issues that require patience to uncover.
patterns.theme: Deep Causal Analysis Over Quick Fixes

patterns.name: Sustainable Strength Building Over Quick Wins
patterns.description: Focus on building stronger companies through root cause resolution rather than achieving quick victories through surface-level tool application.
patterns.context: Organizational development where long-term health requires addressing fundamental issues rather than implementing popular solutions.
patterns.theme: Deep Causal Analysis Over Quick Fixes

examples.name: Root Cause vs. Tool-Throwing Approach
examples.content: Dan's decision architecture centers on 'Root cause' analysis, requiring patience: 'You'll never get to the root cause in the first conversation... even two or three conversations in, you still haven't drilled down into the core issue.' He contrasts this with others who 'just throw ideas and tools out to try to solve those surface-level issues and then declare victory. But it hasn't necessarily built a stronger company.'
examples.theme: Deep Causal Analysis Over Quick Fixes

examples.name: Current Role Frame
examples.content: When asked about his current role perspective, Dan identifies as 'that fractional advisor. You know, COO CFO' - positioning himself as operational and financial leadership rather than pure consulting.
examples.theme: Deep Causal Analysis Over Quick Fixes

principles.name: Owner as Own Roadblock Recognition
principles.description: 'She remains the roadblock two months later, even giving stuff to me that I should be doing. So she just puts it off, puts it off, puts it off.' Understanding that owners often prevent their own progress despite hiring help.
principles.theme: Owner Behavior Pattern Recognition and Correction

principles.name: Urgent vs. Important Distinction
principles.description: 'Some of which might be urgent, most are not. They just happen to be weighing on her mind and probably represent some future path to revenue, some extremely undefined path to future revenue.' Mental burden doesn't equal actual priority.
principles.theme: Owner Behavior Pattern Recognition and Correction

principles.name: True Priorities vs. Revenue Impact
principles.description: 'I'm just listening for what the true priorities are, not necessarily based on revenue impact but based on what it's going to take to get her working on the right things to get her out of the mud.' Priority assessment based on operational effectiveness rather than revenue potential.
principles.theme: Owner Behavior Pattern Recognition and Correction

principles.name: Self-Discovery Through Questioning
principles.description: 'I just start asking questions about each of those so-called priorities. I try to let her talk it through so that she realizes that some of them aren't priorities.' Facilitation over direction for genuine understanding.
principles.theme: Owner Behavior Pattern Recognition and Correction

principles.name: Time Freedom as Priority Test
principles.description: 'What if this week we did nothing more than number two and number three? What impact would that have?' Using time liberation as a metric for identifying true priorities that enable higher-value work.
principles.theme: Owner Behavior Pattern Recognition and Correction

patterns.name: Owner Roadblock Diagnosis and Resolution
patterns.description: Identify when owners themselves are preventing progress through inability to delegate or prioritize, then use questioning to help them recognize this pattern.
patterns.context: Business consulting where owners hire help but continue to bottleneck progress through their own behaviors and decision-making patterns.
patterns.theme: Owner Behavior Pattern Recognition and Correction

patterns.name: Priority Clarification Through Impact Testing
patterns.description: Test claimed priorities by exploring their impact on time freedom and ability to focus on high-value activities rather than just revenue potential.
patterns.context: Strategic planning situations where multiple competing priorities need to be evaluated based on their systemic impact rather than just financial metrics.
patterns.theme: Owner Behavior Pattern Recognition and Correction

patterns.name: Socratic Priority Discovery
patterns.description: Use questioning to guide owners through their own priority list, letting them discover which items aren't actually priorities through their own analysis.
patterns.context: Coaching situations where self-discovery creates stronger buy-in than imposed priorities or external analysis.
patterns.theme: Owner Behavior Pattern Recognition and Correction

examples.name: Shiny Object Owner Roadblock Example
examples.content: Dan worked with an owner who 'loves to chase shiny red objects' and 'remains the roadblock two months later' despite hiring help. When she presented a laundry list of 'fires that have to be put out,' he listened for 'what the true priorities are, not necessarily based on revenue impact but based on what it's going to take to get her working on the right things to get her out of the mud.'
examples.theme: Owner Behavior Pattern Recognition and Correction

examples.name: Time Freedom Priority Test
examples.content: Dan used a specific test: 'what if this week we did nothing more than number two and number three? What impact would that have?' When she said it 'would free up a lot of time long-term,' he reframed: 'is that really our priority to get you to do what you're best at versus all the stuff that you're doing right now? She got it.'
examples.theme: Owner Behavior Pattern Recognition and Correction

principles.name: Family Harmony Over Financial Maximization
principles.description: 'My goal is family harmony... We have to focus on family harmony first and the amount that you get paid second. I did not call me in for that.' Prioritizing relationship preservation over pure financial optimization in family business transitions.
principles.theme: Relationship-First Family Business Strategy

principles.name: Range Over Fixed Number Strategy
principles.description: 'We can't go into this stuck on a number. We come up with a range. What feels good to you?' Using ranges to maintain negotiation flexibility and avoid positional bargaining.
principles.theme: Relationship-First Family Business Strategy

principles.name: Middle Ground for Mutual Concession
principles.description: 'Family harmony becomes that middle ground where people ought to be willing to give a little bit. Both sides ought to be willing to give a little bit.' Creating shared values as foundation for compromise.
principles.theme: Relationship-First Family Business Strategy

principles.name: Family Business Relationship Fragility Recognition
principles.description: 'I've seen too many family businesses where family members don't even talk to each other anymore.' Understanding long-term relationship costs of financial disputes in family contexts.
principles.theme: Relationship-First Family Business Strategy

principles.name: Financial Quarterback Role
principles.description: Positioned as 'sort of that financial quarterback to just be behind the scenes... pulling together the information that is needed and help craft the strategy' - operational support rather than legal advocacy.
principles.theme: Relationship-First Family Business Strategy

patterns.name: Relationship-First Financial Strategy
patterns.description: In family business transitions, prioritize maintaining family relationships over maximizing financial outcomes, using this as the framework for negotiation strategy.
patterns.context: Family business succession where financial disputes can permanently damage relationships and create long-term costs beyond monetary considerations.
patterns.theme: Relationship-First Family Business Strategy

patterns.name: Range-Based Negotiation Framework
patterns.description: Use valuation ranges rather than fixed numbers to prevent positional bargaining and maintain flexibility for relationship-preserving compromises.
patterns.context: Business valuation disputes where rigid positions can escalate conflict and prevent mutually acceptable solutions.
patterns.theme: Relationship-First Family Business Strategy

patterns.name: Values-Based Middle Ground Creation
patterns.description: Establish shared values (like family harmony) as the negotiation foundation that encourages both parties to make concessions for a larger shared goal.
patterns.context: Family or partnership disputes where purely financial negotiations fail to account for relationship preservation needs.
patterns.theme: Relationship-First Family Business Strategy

examples.name: Family Business Valuation Strategy Surprise
examples.content: In a family business valuation dispute between mother and son, Dan surprised the attorney by prioritizing 'family harmony based upon all of the family businesses that I've worked with.' He told the mother: 'We can't go into this stuck on a number. We come up with a range... we have to focus on family harmony first and the amount that you get paid second. I did not call me in for that.'
examples.theme: Relationship-First Family Business Strategy

examples.name: Family Harmony as Negotiation Foundation
examples.content: Dan's thinking: 'Once we start talking about a specific dollar amount, it's easy for either side to just dig in their heels, and family harmony becomes that middle ground where people ought to be willing to give a little bit. Both sides ought to be willing to give a little bit.' His experience: 'I've seen too many family businesses where family members don't even talk to each other anymore.'
examples.theme: Relationship-First Family Business Strategy
